question: You know in some movies how they have a dream sequence only they don't tell you it's a dream? Pull out to reveal Josie on pitcher's mound of a-- Told you. I'm over there. The camera swings to Josie entering. Rhoda, a young copy assistant, tails her, pen and paper in hand. Standard American calls for "er". Standard British is "re". So go for "er", unless you're a pompous American, then go for British. Josie keeps negotiating the maze, leaving Rhoda in her wake.
answer: No way. No way. No way. Ech, hold on. What.

question: Messages? Merkin removes his finger from his nose and uses it to pick up a pink message. He holds it out to Josie. Disgusted, she takes it by one corner.
answer: Seriously? No way. No way-- Josie's still standing there. What

question: Merkin, do you think we could get some more yellow highlighters? I checked the box and we're-- Merkin swivels his chair 180 degrees so his back is to Josie and continues with his phone call.
answer: Okay, I'm back, so-- Josie sighs, walks to her door. It's marked with a lopsided nameplate

question: Guess who I did it with last night...
answer: Roger in Op/Ed.

question: Who told!
answer: You did. Yesterday you said, and I quote, "I have a date with Roger from Op/Ed tonight and I'm going to do it with him."

question: How many times have I fired her?
answer: Five-- Six--

question: Eh. Gus turns to exit.
answer: Hey Gus--did you see the story idea I left on your desk?

question: Yeah--the blind foster home mother. It was good. I got Cahoon on it.
answer: Oh. Cahoon. Yeah, he's--good.

question: Geller, we've been over this. You're a great copy editor. Maybe my best copy editor. You're not a reporter.
answer: You've done five of my ideas.

question: You know what separates us office flunkies from the reporters?
answer: They don't have to be in the office Christmas show?

question: A flack jacket.
answer: A--flack jacket.

question: Every Tom, Dick, and Harry thinks he can write. But a journalist gets in there, right where the bombs are. He's aggressive. Grabs the bull by the balls.
answer: You don't think I can grab bulls' balls?

question: Geller, you don't want a reporter's life. They're very--messy. You're all about order. Control. And getting me my copy by five.
answer: Hey--I can be out of control. Gus smiles. On his way out he re-adjusts Josie's nameplate so it hangs at an angle. Tormented, Josie waits a beat. She can't take it, and runs to the door and straightens it.

question: Copy by five.
answer: Be honest. Do you think I'm aggressive? Anita ponders a moment.

question: Be honest. Do you think I'm aggressive? Anita ponders a moment.
answer: Okay. Remember when they took your office chair in for repairs and forgot to return it?

question: Yeah.
answer: You stood for like a month. Cynthia, an affable African-American woman in her 40's, enters and puts three microwave meals in the microwave.

question: Y'know, maybe Gus has a point. It wouldn't kill you to relax and have some fun. Roger's got a friend, Marshall in editing? The one with the lazy eye? Maybe we could double date.
answer: Forget it.

question: I swear to God, Jos. When is the last time you went on a real live date?
answer: I'm concentrating on my career right now.

question: Do you own any colored underwear? Stripes? Anything?!
answer: Anita!

question: Look. You're way under 30, you're cute, some guys find white Carter's underwear sexy If you talk to his nose, you don't even notice the eye. Josie laughs in spite of herself.
answer: The right guy is out there. I'm just not going to kiss a whole bunch of losers to get to him.

question: Yeah, but sometimes kissing the losers can be a fun diversion.
answer: When I finally get kissed, I'll know. Anita and Cynthia trade looks.

question: Okay. If you've never kissed a guy, we got bigger problems than the underwear.
answer: I've kissed guys. I've just never kissed a guy. Felt that thing--

question: Hey Monty--you think we'll get any business today? I think maybe people are scared off by the tiki torches. I thought people just wanted their mail delivered on time. Josie walks into the store, triggering Hawaiian music. Monty puts a lei over her head. Relax, Monty. It's just my sister. Monty takes the lei off her neck. Josie hands Rob an envelope. Rob rifles through the cash inside. Thanks, Jos. I'll pay you back. Bambi thanks you, too. Rob indicates a beat-up wreck of a yellow car parked outside.
answer: That is so--weird that you name your car.

question: No it's not. Guys name their penises.
answer: Okaaaay.... That car's going to bankrupt you.

question: She just needs a new windshield wiper.
answer: Because I bought the windshield last week. I'm a hubcap away from owning more of Bambi than you do. Rob hands the money back.

question: Y'know what? Take it. I don't want it. Josie hands it back.
answer: Rob, take the money, okay? It's no big deal.

question: No, it is. It's just one more thing to add to your "things that make you a better person than me" list.
answer: Better person than I.

question: See!
answer: I know this woman. She works in admissions at Lakeshore Community? She might be able to get you in for the Fall semester. Maybe she could get you the baseball scholarship, and I could help and--

question: I'm not going to college, Jos. And I'm not playing anymore baseball. This is my life.
answer: This--this is a luau that sells packing material!

question: Someday this luau is going to be all mine!
answer: How can you just give up like that? You had a real shot at playing college ball and you let one case of mono stop everything. Don't you want more? To move out of Mom and Dad's? Pay your own bills?

question: Oh yay! And then I could be as happy as you!
answer: For your information, I am very happy. Deliriously happy. I lead a very happy life! She exits. The music starts up again. There. What d'you think, guys? Where should it go? Josie looks around the living room. Hmm. What's that? Bedroom? Great idea! She walks into the bedroom with the pillow. Perfect.

question: Turns out he's allergic to peanuts. And I think -- holy shit. I don't even know my own kids. I mean, who knows if they're even mine? And it got me thinking. How much do we know about kids today? What are they thinking? How many of them are allergic to peanuts? Boom. It hit me -- "My Semester In High School." Camera stops at a bald guy, the jerks over one seat to Josie. You. What's your name.
answer: Josie. Josie Geller.

question: You enroll on Friday. General crowd hubub. Josie's in shock.
answer: Oh. But--I'm not a reporter yet...

question: And none of these geezers could pass for a day under 40. Have fun. And Rigfort exits.
answer: It's finally happening, Anita! I'm going to write! Anita looks concerned. My own undercover feature - "Written by Josie Geller".

question: Okay, just so I'm clear here -- neither of you think I can do this.
answer: Jos, that's not what we're --

question: Anita, when you wanted to seduce the guy in the mailroom and you didn't think you could learn Spanish fast enough, who quizzed you on your verbs? Anita looks down, chastened.
answer: Senorita Josie.

question: You can start by handing me that bag. Anita does. Josie sticks it over her face, flips her head between her knees and starts hyperventilating again. Close up on Rob, wearing his Tiki Post outfit. He shakes his head.
answer: No. Uh, uh. Pull out to reveal him standing with Josie on the sidewalk in front of -

question: It's just for a couple of months.
answer: You can't just "borrow" my car for a couple of months! That's like ten years in Bambi life!

question: I'll give you my Buick Le Sabre. Rob rolls his eyes and enters the store. You can name it whatever you want.
answer: Wow. This must be big.

question: I got an assignment from the paper. I'm going undercover. Back to high school. Rob starts laughing uncontrollably. What!?
answer: Do you remember high school?

question: It was a long time ago -
answer: Don't you remember what they called you? Slowly Josie's face falls. She looks very far away. Josie -

question: Josie Grossie.
answer: I know. I came up with it. You look nauseous.

question: Nauseated. I look nauseated. Oh God. She puts her hand over her mouth, races for the bathroom. Hey, Billy Prince, I noticed you weren't in math today, and I have the notes in case you want - Midway through Josie's speech, we hear the odd sound of liquid hitting linoleum. Josie follow Billy's gaze down to between her feet where a pool of Sprite has gathered. Billy starts to laugh. Kids around him join in. As the laughter echoes around her we DISSOLVE BACK TO: This is a very bad idea.
answer: So, you were a geek. Big deal.

question: Anita, remember espadrilles?
answer: Please. That doesn't make you a nerd. Everyone wore those shoes.

question: The girls threw them at me in the locker room.
answer: Okay. That's bad.

question: At the end of the yeat the person who got the most direct his to my head got to toss me into the pool.
answer: Mama mia. Just because you were a nerd once doesn't mean it's going to happen again. That's why you have me for fashion consultation. Anita pulls a slip skirt off a rack and holds it up. Now this is cute.

question: That is lingerie.
answer: So I was thinking about what you were saying - y'know, about really being kissed? I think Roger could be the one.

question: What'd you feel when you kissed him?
answer: Bridgework?

question: Very romantic. Josie pulls out a plain button-down cardigan. How about this?
answer: I am not letting you out of the house in that, young lady. Anita grabs an awful white maribou jacket and matching earrings and holds them up. Cuuuute!

question: 'Nita, this is about reporting, not accessorizing.
answer: And we're going to have to do something about your hair.

question: Anita!
answer: Jos, please try and have some fun here, okay? How many of us get to go back to high school? You're gonna have a blast! SMASH CUT TO

question: Josie, in my classroom, tardiness is unacceptable --
answer: I'm really sorry -- Ms. Knox pulls a ridiculously huge sombrero out from under her desk. The class laughs in recognition.

question: Not as sorry as I am. Ms. Knox puts the sombrero on a less-than-thrilled Josie. Ole! Ten minutes in this hat, you'll never be late again. So, let's hear something about you. Stand up. Stand up. Josie does. The sombrero drops over her eyes. She adjusts it so she can read her notecards. CLOSE UP on the notecard --it's filled with precise script under a heading
answer: My name is Josie. I'm a high school student. I came from -- Just then the classroom door opens. We see from Josie's perspective a blinding light, Josie squints. From the light emerges a shadowy vision of Billy Prince. Billy? Josie blinks, REVEAL not Billy, but a beautiful guy, Guy. He stands very close to her. Bali. I'm from Billy-Bali. It's a suburb of Bali proper. Guy pushes past her, tosses a wooden hall pass to Ms. Knox, and moves to his seat.

question: Bali. Fascinating! What did your family do there? Josie looks around in panic, sees a student in a South Glen South windbreaker with huge ram on the back.
answer: We were--sheep--farmers. We raised sheep. In Billy-Bali. Josie realizes the trouble she's gotten herself into. Oh my God. Oh my God--do I miss Billy-Bali. It had--a really great...aquarium. She sits. Defeated. Note to self--Research Bali. Kill Anita for picking out this outfit. Find and destroy sombrero.

question: 'As You Like It" is an example of a Shakespearean-- Sam turns to the blackboard and starts writing. We CU on his butt, hardly discernable in his loose 501 jeans, all the girls swoon. SAM Pastoral Comedy. Anyone know what that means? An enthusiastic, if slightly dim girl, SERA, waves her hand.
answer: Oh oh oh! That's what they do to milk!

question: That's pasteurize, Sera. But close. Same letter-- --three syllables--
answer: Parakeet?! ALDYS

question: Right, right. Josie picks up her notepad and her pen. So - tell me about yourselves. They all just stare at Josie in disgust. Guy approaches their table.
answer: I'm Guy. Guy looks at Josie. He's beautiful. She's flustered.

question: Yes you are. A guy. Guy. Quite a guy. Oh my. Look at that--I rhymed. Yikes. Bikes!
answer: Are you in special ed? Josie stands up, grabs her bag and her chocolate milk-

question: Bye. Guy. Others. She leaves the Cafeteria, passing a-couple of Denominators. Aaaah! How old am I? Must--have--water-- Oh--my--God--you guys arestill telling that lie--? Rhoda, make sure Gus gets-the whole message, okay? Yeah--bye-- Josie arrives where she parked Bambi. The space is empty. She still holds the phone to her ear-- Wait a second-- No, not you--bye-- Josie shuts the phone, looks around...retraces her steps ... Bambi is gone. Josie walks around the lot, getting visibly upset. In the corner of the lot, we see a group of Denominators removing a BIG METAL CHAIN from around a group of tightly packed cars. Who's of they? Aldys motions up to a second floor window. Guy and his Group look down on them, laughing.
answer: Guy Perkins and his amazing Lemmings. They push your car out of its space, hide it, then watch while you look for it. We've taken to chaining ours together for safety. I'm Aldys.

question: I'm Josie. Aldys is an interesting name.
answer: When it's not yours. My mom was going through her Harlequin Romance phase.

question: Try being named after a guitar-playing pussycat. Aldys doesn't get it. Never mind. That is so awful that they hide your cars.
answer: I guess. Although, what is truly awful is that with the combined intellectual effort of every kid in that room right now- She points up to the biology room- They still would not know the difference between a synecdoche and a hyperbole. Josie laughs.

question: I know. It's pathetic. Aldys stares Josie down. What?
answer: Well, do you?

question: Synecdoche uses a part to represent a whole- as in " head of cattle", whereas a hyperbole is simple exaggeration like "I could eat a horse."
answer: Nice. They stop and look around.

question: How long will they watch us for?
answer: Until Guy tells them to go. Once they watched me for like two hours. I found my car the next day in the T.J. Maxx parking lot.

question: Why do they listen to Guy? ALDYS Yeah. Let's do that. They start to walk out of the parking lot. Josie is visibly thrilled - having finally found a friend.
answer: Yeah - isn't it amazing that those guys are our same age? I mean, they just seem so much younger, you know.

question: Oh I know. A WAITER delivers two huge chocolate shakes.
answer: I'm going to be so happy to get to college. I hear at Northwestern they don't make fun of you for knowing the element table.

question: Hey--I went to Northwestern! Once. To use the bathroom. OUT THE WINDOW, Josie sees her Buick with Rob at the wheel stopped at a red light. Detailed on to the side in big white script is Oh. My. God. You'll really like Northwestern. They both slurp down their shakes. So what are your hopes, your dreams, what do you want to be?
answer: Professor of medieval literature. Novelist. Weekend flautist. Aldys takes another slurp of her shake. WE HEAR a muffled cell phone RINGING. I think your knapsack is ringing. Josie takes the cell phone out of her knapsack and answers it.

question: Hello? WE INTERCUT WITH:
answer: Geller, I got your message. What the hell kind of story are you pitching?! Josie smiles awkwardly at Aldys, covering the phone.

question: It's my dad. He worries. Hi, Dad. I miss you too.
answer: You're a sick puppy, Geller. Josie indicates to Aldys she'll be right back and walks to the back of the restaurant by the pay phones.

question: It's an expose on cafeteria food.
answer: And you're leading with the terrible truth about cole slaw?!

question: Well, the bulk of it will be about the pimento loaf--
answer: Geller...you wanna be a reporter? Take a look at what sells! Sex scandals. Bribery. People jumping off buildings. So unless a kid just killed himself because he was being paid to have sex with the school mascot in a big vat of this cole slaw, you got nothing! Gus slams down his phone.

question: You didn't taste the pimento loaf. She looks back to the table where Aldys is dividing the check.
answer: They love to disconnect the battery, too. She looks under the hood, reconnects the battery. Slams the hood down. Just so you know, I think they recalled these cars in 1974.

question: Thanks.
answer: Sure. No problem. Aldys heads to the lot for her car, and then turns around. Hey, Josie, how are you at Calculus?

question: Petty good.
answer: How would you like to join The Denominators? The Math Team could really use a new brain. We lost our best logarithm guy last year.

question: "No sooner had they met but they looked; no sooner looked but they loved; no sooner loved but they sighed..." Josie's voice begins to fade away- Does he notice me? Does he hear my heart screaming his name-- sometimes it's so loud I think the Gods can hear my pain. His voice is so mellifluous, oh to get just one small kiss. The CLASS laughs at her except for Billy, who smiles at her, looking slightly touched.
answer: O.K., what have you wanted for like ever but you didn't think it would -ever happen? Josie looks at her for a moment, mulling it over.

question: That they'd start an Olympic team for grammar - like diagramming sentences and verb declensions and stuff. And I'm scouted for the team- just as an alternate, of course- because I'm so young. But then there's talk of me in the '96 games- I'm the most popular girl in school, and Billy Prince is taking me to prom. Josie laughs at the absurdity. She looks at Sheila. Sheila is dead serious.
answer: Yes.

question: What?
answer: Billy Prince is asking you to prom.

question: Why?
answer: I don't know.

question: The poem! I knew he liked the poem! Billy Prince is asking me to the prom.
answer: That's what I'm saying. The two girls look at each other. Big smiles erupt into screams, as they jump up and down, hugging each other. SFX - The BELL RINGS.

question: What is with this school and prom?
answer: Southglen South competes every year for best prom, and usually they win. We Denominators don't even go to prom. -But to everyone else it's huge.

question: Aldys, don't miss your prom--it only happens once.
answer: This one has been so hyped. We're tied for most wins with Northglen North. This year's winner will determine the winner of the century. The theme is everything. So whatever Southglen picks has to be totally unique-- INTERIOR. NORTHGLEN NORTH HIGH SCHOOL - DAY KIDS all stare at a loudspeaker. KID'S VOICE

question: I left my bag in English. I'll see you later. Josie dashes down the hallway.
answer: Whoa. Deja Vu.

question: Sorry. Forgetful. Josie picks up her bookbag. She notices the book Sam's reading-- Dorothy Parker--
answer: You like her?

question: I love the way she writes.
answer: Not the happiest of souls. "Art is a form of catharsis, and love is a permanent flop."

question: But I think she wanted to be happy, that's why she wrote. I mean, she was still writing about love, right?
answer: True. I guess she hadn't completely given up hope. Are you sure you're seventeen?

question: Sure, why?
answer: Because seventeen-year-olds do not like writers from the '30's. They don't even like people in their 30's.

question: Well, I'm definitely seventeen and now definitely late-- And she smiles and runs out.
answer: we should be spending it thinking of how we can better serve your baby-sitting needs?

question: What's that?
answer: That's the old drive-in. They call it "The Court". Now it's just a continuous party for Guy's group. ANGLE ON

question: Yeah, I know.
answer: I mean, what if they just stupid to hide the fact that they're actually brainiacs with super powers and they're plotting to take over the world and make my life hell until I die? ANGLE ON

question: Wow, if it isn't Alpo. Coming out to sniff some hydrants? Josie is frozen, but not Aldys.
answer: Oh, Guy, you on a little break from having an original thought? Ooops, I forgot, that's all the time. Tyke gets it, and laughs. Guy doesn't get it at all.

question: You guys aren't seriously trying to hang out at The Court?
answer: oooh, cheap wine coolers and a fire in a trashcan. Where do I sign up?

question: And stay away from prom.
answer: Last I checked--this was still a free country.

question: Have you ever wanted to go to The Court?
answer: Are you kidding, Josie? It's lame. All they do is stand around and get drunk. It's lame.

question: It is?
answer: Yes, it's lame.

question: Yeah, it sounds lame. Why would we want to go there, and stand around?
answer: Exactly.

question: Josie, I am appalled. Josie picks up the paper, and starts reading intently.
answer: Jeez, so am I. I had no idea that these kids- let's see- turn to A14- She tries to turn to A14, but Gus grabs the paper out of her hands in a rage.

question: No, I am appalled that I have a reporter in there, undercover, for almost three weeks now- I had to read about this in the Tribune.
answer: Oh. Right. Gus angrily tries to fold the paper back 'up. He's having a hard time. Josie tries to help, but he yanks it away. Gus reads aloud from the newspaper.

question: Responding officers found minors, marijuana, and cheap wine coolers when they responded to a call to break up a party at what Southglen High Schoolers have come to call "The Court." Seventeen-year-old Kristen Rey says, "Yeah, everyone who's anyone is at The Court on Saturday night."
answer: Kristen got a quote? Gus looks up at Josie. Yes, urm, she's right. I have learned it is a very popular place for the young people to go.

question: Have you been there?
answer: Uhh, no.

question: Have you been to any parties?
answer: Well, how would you define to parties"? Because we ordered a deli platter at this one Denominator drill session-- Gus looks like he may combust. He opens the newspaper, finds what he's looking for, and shoves it in Josie's face. It is a picture of all of the popular kids at Southglen- Kristen, Kirsten, Gibby, Guy- they are all posing for the picture at The Court, smiling and holding beers.

question: This is where the stories are. You are going to become friends with these people. You are going to party with them. You are going to hang out with them on weekends. When they go to prom, you are going to be in their same damn limo!
answer: Gus I, the popular kids and I, we just don't- I mean, I don't think I can do this. He points to the picture in the paper of the Popular Kids.

question: Do you even know these kids?
answer: They hid my car-- Gus leans in very close.

question: Get to know them. Very well. Your job and my job depends on it.
answer: Depend on it. No s. Your subject is plural.

question: Are mom and dad here?
answer: No. They're at the Franklin Hint Expo at the Skokie Holiday Inn.

question: Good. She shoves her way into the house. Rob follows. I can't do it. I thought I could. I can't. I give up--I'm never going to be a reporter. Rob sits next to her on the couch. He looks up at the T.V.-, which is now off.
answer: Did you catch the score? Josie gives him a look of death. No, I mean, no big whoop.

question: I can't do this. She pulls the article out of her purse, and shoves it at Rob. He sees the picture of all the popular kids at The Court.
answer: These girls are high schoolers? Damn, we've got some underage hotties on our hands, here!

question: Gus insists that I become friends with these kids. The popular kids. It's impossible.
answer: Why is that impossible? Josie's eyes get teary.

question: Rob, you don't know how it was for me back in high school. No one ever threw juice boxes at you in the hallway. You never dreamed about being popular- you already were. All I wanted was to be accepted, and they just fucking tortured me. I can't do all that again. I can't go back to Southglen South.
answer: Oh my God! You're at Southglen South? They have a killer baseball team.

question: Rob. Please focus. He puts his arm around her.
answer: Jos, you've been to college, you're successful, you wash your hair now-- you're not Josie Grossie anymore.

question: Don't you realize how much I wanted to be you in high school? Just for one minute to feel what it was like to be popular?
answer: Come on! It's not that hard. All you need is one person. Once the right person thinks you're cool, you're in. Everyone else will be too scared to question it.

question: Is that true?
answer: Little known fact. Josie takes this in. Look, don't you wanna show them - Gus, Billy Prince, yourself--that you're not freaked out by the cool kids anymore? That you can go in there, be friends with them, and get your story?

question: Yes, desperately.
answer: Plus, if you quit you're no better than me.

question: Better than I...
answer: That's the spirit!

question: George! What are you doing here?
answer: Just get in the van, Josie.

question: What is this?
answer: Hidden camera.

question: Wings?
answer: We used it for our expose on overweight flight attendants--"Is That Why They Never Give You a Second Bag of Nuts?"

question: I'm not doing this until I speak with Gus.
answer: Geller, stop being a pain in the ass. Josie looks all around.

question: Gus?
answer: No, it's the Great and Powerful Oz. Now listen--you're in over your head. This is how it's gonna work. I review the tapes, I find your story.

question: What if I say no?
answer: I bet Good Housekeeping would go gaga over the cole slaw piece. Off Josie's look of concern...

question: Hey! Kirsten, Kristen, Gibby-- What's up girlfriends? The three girls pause and turn just as Josie, caught up in the moment, doesn't see a stray backpack on the stairs in front of her. Josie trips and-- JOSIE-CAM POV And so it is Rosalind, in disguise, who is best able to see through the disguises of others. To say to Phebe, "Mistress, know thy self," to look at love from every angle, and to realize, finally, that she is in love with Orlando-- The BELL RINGS. Class is over. Josie puts her stuff away and starts to follow the Cool Girls out. Hey guys, wait up-- The Girls keep moving. Sam stops Josie.
answer: Hey, Josie, hold on. You've been hiding something from me.

question: Oh I don't think so.
answer: Your writing. It's amazing, Josie. You're really talented. And far less depressing than Dorothy Parker.

question: Thank you.
answer: So what are you thinking for college?

question: College. Haven't really thought about it.
answer: That's crazy. I'll get you some applications.

question: Oh no no no no no. See, my family, we don't go to college. We just go right into sheep herding.
answer: Josie you owe it to yourself to go. For your writing. You're a natural.

question: Thanks. Wow. That's--really nice to hear.
answer: Josie, you're different. When you speak in class, I can tell--You actually feel the words-- in here. They're alive. Like-Eurdora Welty talked about the word it moon"? How for her it was like a Concord grape. "That Grandpa took off his vine and gave to me to suck out of its skin--" SAM/JOSIE It --and swallow whole." They both take a breath in. Look away from each other. INTERIOR. GEORGE'S VAN  SAME George watches the monitor.

question: Showtime's over! Move-it! Back to work! Anita climbs off his desk.
answer: Gus, have you ever been in love?

question: Leave.
answer: Oh give it up, Gus. I'm just making conversation.

question: Love. Who knows what that is? Now circulation, deadlines, those I understand.
answer: You should go out every now and then, Gus; with some new ties the girls would be all over you. Gus stares down at his tie. But he's smiling--a little.

question: Go away. I have enough work here to last me all night.
answer: Listen, I don't have any plans--you want some help?

question: No Roger from op/ed?
answer: Nope. They share a smile. INTERIOR. HIGH SCHOOL HALLWAY  DAY Josie walks toward her locker, the Make out Couple is at it again. Josie's fed up. She taps the Boy on his shoulder.

question: Excuse me. Hi. Do you guys have some kind of schedule I could work around? He ignores Josie and goes back to his Girlfriend. Aldys, in her Denominator sweatshirt decorated with pins, approaches Josie.
answer: Hey, where's your sweatshirt?

question: I  uhh, must have forgotten-
answer: No biggie. I have an extra in my locker. I'll get it for you. She starts to leave. Oh  I almost forgot  I'll see you tonight at Big Cup. 7:30, right? Josie looks confused. Remember, that poet that we liked  the reading he's doing at Big Cup? I got us tickets.

question: Right. 7:30.
answer: I'm late for lab. Aldys takes off. Josie looks down the hall, where Guy, Kristen and the others are all looking at a flyer pasted to the wall.

question: I am not 21. I am only seventeen and I still attend high school. The bouncer stamps her hand. She looks down at her hand. WE CU ON her hand, reading DELLOSER. She enters as the two Stoners approach the Bouncer.
answer: Josie--out on a school night. A woman, LARA, emerges from the crowd. And puts her arm around SAM. An awkward beat.

question: Hi.
answer: Oh, right, sorry. Lara--Josie. Josie--Lara. Josie's a student of mine. Lara's my-date.

question: Hi. Is it okay if I sit here? Get it?! Get it?! He was a firecracker! She lifts up Rasta 1's dreadlocks to get his ear. A firecracker! And she cracks up again. Oh my God! This music rules! And Josie proceeds to get up and take over the place--she's dancing on the table, getting up with the band and playing the bongos, all with absolutely no rhythm or style. But with a lot of whooping. The club is agog. ANGLE ON
answer: She's from Bali. And as Josie continues to dance on stage, making a total fool of herself, Jimmy Cliff turns to CAMERA. JIMMY

question: WE HEAR THE LAUGHING, the JOSIE CAM JERKS frantically from KID to KID.
answer: This can not be good-- Oh man. Look up, girl. C'mon, Look up--

question: George is now apoplectic.
answer: LOOK IN THE MIRROR!

question: As every loser should. I've been in a horrible accident. This is a coma-induced nightmare.
answer: No. Josie, this is real. She looks up.

question: Oh my God! That's worse! What are you doing here?! Rob leans in and whispers to Josie.
answer: I just registered. Rob whips out his fake ID and shows it to her. Manufactured at the Tiki Post. Rob helps Josie up.

question: Are you crazy?! You can't do this.
answer: This is it Jos! This is my ninth inning! The game isn't over--I just thought it was! I get on the Southglen baseball team, the right scout sees me-- I'm into the minors-it's game time!

question: You're twenty-three years old!
answer: With the reading comprehension of a fifteen year old! Plus, I'm popular... You want to be popular... I can recognize a cry for help when I see one.

question: Hey  where were you last night? I was worried. Josie can't take her eyes off Rob sitting at Guy's table. Aldys notices Josie's distraction.
answer: What?

question: Last night. 7:30. Big Cup. I kept calling you, but I only got your machine. I don't even know your parents line and I was really worried.
answer: Oh. I forgot. Aldys is really hurt.

question: This seat taken?
answer: Thank you. He gets in. The ride JERKS into motion.

question: Whoa. They start a slow ascent. Sam seems ill at ease.
answer: Are you--scared?

question: I'm gonna tell you something here, and I hope it doesn't undermine my position as an authority figure. I'm a little afraid of heights.
answer: You're afraid of the Ferris wheel.

question: Actually, it's more the plunging head first into the crowd part that gets me.
answer: Oh right. The Spiderman incident.

question: You remember that story?
answer: Of course. I remember everything from your class. They smile at each other. The smile is interrupted by a HEAVY SWAYING of their bucket, caused by Tommy ROCKING in the bucket ahead. Sam looks a little green.

question: Yoooooow.
answer: Don't look down! They're facing the ground at this point.

question: Out of my control. TOMMY! CUT IT OUT! ENOUGH! Tommy stops. Sam turns to Josie. I said that as a chaperone. They start to ascend again. Sam relaxes. SAM Okay This is okay. Smooth. Can I ask you something? Do you think I tell too many stories in class?
answer: That's what makes you interesting. As a teacher.

question: God, I would love to think I'm an interesting teacher. I mean, I had maybe one or two teachers in high school who had any passion at all.
answer: You do. Seem to. Have passion. In the classroom.

question: You have to say that. You're my student.
answer: I don't have to say that. They look into each other's eyes just as Tommy RATTLES his bucket ruthlessly.

question: Boys.
answer: I know.

question: I'd like to tell you that we all grow out of it, but that's a lie. Some of us will always be rattling cages.
answer: Why do you do that?

question: I don't know. And you know what's scary--when you get older it just gets more confusing. I've spent the last ten years with women who are basically all wrong for me. You know what, I shouldn't be talking about this stuff with you.
answer: That's okay. It's nice to have someone to talk to-- The bucket is rocked again by Tommy--Sam grips the safety bar.

question: Same here. They stop rocking but they're still stuck at the top. SAM All I can tell you is that when you're my age, the guys will be lined up around the block for you. They share a smile.
answer: You have to say that. You're my teacher.

question: I shouldn't say that, because I'm your teacher. They look at each other, their smiles fading into realization. Suddenly, the car jerks, and they start to move down. Josie and Sam are pulled out of their reverie. They smile awkwardly at each other and laugh a small laugh. WIDE SHOT of the Ferris wheel as Josie and Sam descend. Thanks, Josie. This wasn't as bad as I thought.
answer: When are you going to open your eyes?

question: Hi. You're here for the sex talk?
answer: Well. I like a man who gets to the point.

question: You're Pam?
answer: If you say so. Sam turns to the class.

question: Welcome juniors and seniors, this is Pam Kitterman. She's our district health counselor. She's here to lead our sex discussion. He ushers a surprised Anita to the front of the room. Josie reacts.
answer: I am? Oh, I am. Hi. Okay. Sex. Yes, well, sex. What's to say really, y'know? You like a guy, you do it. Sometimes he calls. Sometimes he doesn't. Anita leans into Josie, talks sotto. ANITA Hi!

question: God, I can't do this.
answer: Maybe because we're not supposed to be having sex with bananas.

question: You know what, though? I feel like I'm really ready to do it. To have sex for the first time.
answer: Wow. That's big. I mean sex is a really big deal. You shouldn't do it until you know you've found the right person. ANGLE ON SAM, listening. Josie is oblivious. You know, Adele penguins pick one mate. They spend their whole life looking for that one other penguin and when they find it, they know. That's the penguin they stay with for the rest of their lives.

question: Maybe we should go in a different room?
answer: I already checked. There are some pretty serious couples in there. Guy reaches for the doorknob. Wow, Rob's sister must be such a loser. Josie manages a weak smile. Guy sits on the bed. Come here, sit down. She sits on the bed, and then sees a picture of her and her family on the bedside table. She dives across the bed to overturn it. I'm sure you've probably heard that I want to ask you, but I'd like to know if you'd go to prom with me. I know we didn't hit it off right at the beginning but-

question: Yes. I'll go. Yes. Guy leans in as if to kiss her and whispers...
answer: Rufus. But I don't even know where you live.

question: You know what? Why don't you just pick me up here? We could all share a limo.
answer: Cool. I'll catch you later. Guy leaves. Josie is ecstatic and flops back on her bed. Stuffed animals fall all around her.

question: Rob, this is unbelievable. I mean-- Josie shoves through the double doors leading into the gym. --I spent my whole life wanting to fit in, and now-- Gibby and Kirsten run up to Josie.
answer: Hey Josie- who did Archie date Betty or Veronica?

question: Betty. Gibby turns to Kirsten.
answer: Told you. And they move off. Rob spots Tracy and moves off to her.

question: You're really doing a great job here, Josie. I like your "can do" attitude.
answer: Thanks. They weren't related to Humpty Dumpty, were they? Tweedle Dum and Tweedle Dee?

question: Maybe distant cousins. They did have that egg shape in common.
answer: But Humpty Dumpty was alone.

question: That's sad, isn't it? He had to sit on that wall all by himself. He deserved to have somebody.
answer: That's really what we all need, right? Someone to sit up on the wall with us--

question: Yeah. To watch the world go by.--
answer: To put us back together again when we fall. They share a meaningful glance and a smile.

question: Our penguin, right?
answer: Do you think you'll find her?

question: Yeah, actually I do. They are lost in each other. They lean closer, as if they may kiss, then Sam breaks the moment. Oh my God! I almost forgot--I got you a meeting with the admissions guy from Dartmouth!
answer: What! But--I wasn't even going to go to college--

question: No, I know, but I pulled some strings, got him to look at your writing, and he agreed to meet you.
answer: Oh--yikes!

question: I told him --if I'm wrong about this girl, you can take away my teaching certificate!
answer: Wow. You believe in me that much--

question: That's your story!
answer: You're crazy. I can't--I can't-no. No.

question: It's got it all--sex, intrigue, immorality in the education system--
answer: He's my teacher!

question: And that's the best part. "Teacher-Student Relations
answer: There is no lid! Nothing's going on between Sam and me. Coulson. Mr. Sam Coulson and me.

question: Not yet. Every person in this office comes in here and watches you guys! It's like the goddamn Young and the Restless! Rigfort's salivating over it.
answer: You already pitched this to Rigfort?! Gus leans in, now all business.

question: Wow, Josie- you look really-
answer: Rufus?

question: Yes. Exactly. Major Rufus.
answer: Thanks. And what are -

question: Duh. Tom Cruise. "Risky Business". He puts on his black wayfarer sunglasses, and does the famous slide into the living room. Josie laughs.
answer: Rob--thanks. For everything. This is really happening. I never thought--

question: Are you having fun?
answer: Yeah. Definitely. He tries to stand her up on her own.

question: Good. Gibby gave me champagne.
answer: Maybe we should sit. He helps her to a chair next to the dance floor. They both sit. Next to them, a ravenous MISS PIGGY eats with her date KERMIT looking on. She picks up an hors d'oeuvre and stares at it horrified.

question: Rob, I've - I've thought about it a lot. And I think- I mean, I know. You're the one. My penguin. Rob looks at her. She's young. She's beautiful. She's tipsy. She's trying to put her legs behind her head.
answer: Wow - I-

question: Rob, I mean it. I want you to be my first. Me and you. Once the floor stops spinning, let's have sex. He looks around. It's high school prom. A skinny kid is getting beat up in a corner. Other kids are sneaking smokes. He can't do this.
answer: I'm gonna get you some water. And then, I think we should get back out on that dance floor and boogie. Rob gets up, kisses Tracy on the top of her head, and heads for the refreshment table. Tracy, her leg still around her head falls backwards into Kermit's lap. Kermit looks down, surprised and interested. Miss Piggy notices, gives him a big "Harumph", tosses her hair, and leaves. ANGLE BACK ON

question: Hey--what are you thinking about?
answer: Shakespeare. How he described a night like this--"Look how the floor of heaven is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold". What about you? What are you thinking about?

question: My sword. It's like a switch has been flicked on in Josie's brain.
answer: Oh.

question: Josie, you rock my world. You're like the most amazing girl I've ever dated. You're so smart and fun and crazy! You rock my world.
answer: You said that already.

question: You said that already.
answer: Josie--you make a really beautiful prom queen.

question: Thanks. So do you. They both laugh, embarrassed, at Josie's flub.
answer: I always feel like such a goofball in these penguin suits. Like I'm at my own wedding or something. An awkward beat. You wanna-- He gestures towards the dance floor. Josie smiles.

question: Proms always make me sad. They're so final. Graduation. Everyone's scattering, moving on.
answer: Well, are you here with anybody?

question: No, I'm alone.
answer: It's weird because "prom" is actually from the word "promenade". And you can't really promenade alone, can you? Sam smiles at this.

question: You're amazing, Josie Geller. ANGLE ON So--have you thought anymore about Dartmouth?
answer: Yeah, I have. CLOSE UP on Josie's HAND as she subtlety removes her hidden camera pin and drops it to the ground. There's something I have to tell you-- Her foot comes down on top of it.

question: So--surprise! He shakes his head in disbelief and walks off. Josie chases after him. He turns back to her.
answer: "Surprise!" you were doing a story on me?!

question: No, surprise, I thought you'd be--
answer: What? Happy? Why? Because it turns out all along that I was allowed to be attracted to you?

question: You were attracted to me?
answer: Goddamnit, Josie! Drop the act. Do you have any idea what I went through every night because of you?! I was attracted to a 17 year old! When I wasn't taking cold showers, I was trying to figure out what the hell I was going to do when I couldn't teach anymore! I thought I was the one being unethical.

question: Wait, I was going to tell you--
answer: You set me up. For a story. You know what's crazy? I was actually considering waiting for you.

question: But now you don't have to--
answer: Now I don't want to! I bought all of your penguin crap. I thought I found her--the right one! And the problem was she was too young! No - the problem was--she didn't even exist!

question: I did exist. I do exist. I'm the same person!
answer: The person I cared about wouldn't have done this. Everything out of your mouth has been a complete lie. I don't know you at all. For all I know you could hate Dorothy Parker.

question: I don't! Look, you could get to know me, again. Sam turns and starts to walk away. Please. Please don't walk away.
answer: I just can't look at you the same way. Sam gets into his car and drives off. Josie is devastated.

question: Josie, finally. I just wanted to come over and make sure you're okay.
answer: Really? He gets up. He's not happy.

question: No- not really, Josie. NOT REALLY. How could you do that to me? I helped you. I got you everything you wanted. And how do you repay me- you blow everything TWO DAYS before pro scouts come to see me play. Once they had seen me really play- they wouldn't have given a shit about my age.
answer: I wasn't even thinking about-

question: We are not screwed. Yes, I made a mistake. But we will have a story. You will have an amazing story. Josie exits.
answer: Josie! Josie, how'd it go? Did he ream you?

question: Yeah, but I'm okay. I've got some work to do.
answer: You need my help?

question: Josie still stands there. The clock is down to 2:30. She looks over to the dugout.
answer: The Denominators talking and laughing. Behind them, sit the Marching Band EXTERIOR. PITCHER'S MOUND  SAME Josie forces-a stoic smile. 1:00 is on the clock. The cool crowd. Guy, Kirsten and the gang. They are trying start the wave, but its not working.

question: The clock reads
answer: Everyone - including all the Denominators are on their feet, chanting. Aldys cheers the loudest. Guy and the Gang are on their feet.
